document.docAuthor: Fan, Zhi-Hua, Li, Zi-Zhong & Dai, Ren-Huai
document.docTitle: Thagria decussata Fan & Dai, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Taxonomic study of the leafhopper genus Thagria Melichar (Hemiptera: Cicadellidae: Coelidiinae) from Guangxi, China

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Taxonomic study of the leafhopper genus Thagria Melichar (Hemiptera: Cicadellidae: Coelidiinae) from Guangxi, China

subSubSection.paragraph: Description. Body length of male 8.2 mm, female 9.5 mm.

Body slightly robust, medium (
Figs. 60
, 70 ). Crown with four transverse bands, from base to apex brown, black, ivory and black; ocelli and eyes brown (
Figs. 62
, 72 ). Face with clypeus with three black-brown bands, anterior band narrowest, middle widest, distal longest crossing lora and genae; clypellus apical half blackish brown, remainder of face light yellow in male or deep yellow in female (
Figs. 63
, 73 ). Pronotum densely covered with yellow-brown nubs and traversed by three bands: black anteriorly, ivory medially, posteriorly brown (
Figs. 62
, 72 ). Mesonotum brown, with yellowish white spots (
Figs. 62
, 72 ). Forewing fuscous, with numerous transparent ivory and ivory-yellow patches, venation black with orange spots (
Figs. 60, 61
,
70, 71
).

Head in dorsal view anteriorly rounded, crown wider than eye width, produced about 1 / 4 of crown midline anterad of eyes, coronal suture evident, about half of median length, disk flat (
Figs. 62
, 72 ). Face with clypeus long, lateral margins slightly convex; clypellus short, base broad, inflated (male) or slightly inflated (female), wider than clypeus at juncture of clypeal suture, apical half constricted, apex truncate (
Figs. 63
, 73 ). Crown, pronotum and mesonotum midline ratio about 1 : 1 :1.5 (
Figs. 62
, 72 ). Forewing long, apex rounded, appendix narrowed (
Figs. 60, 61
,
70, 71
).

Type material.
Holotype : ♂ , CHINA : Guangxi, Damingshan, Alt. 800–1300 m ,
5–10 Aug. 2011
, coll. Yang Zaihua ( GUGC ). Paratype : ♀, same data as holotype ( GUGC ).

Etymology. The new species name is derived from the Latin word “
decussata
” meaning “the figure X” for the X-shaped paraphysis in lateral view.

Remarks. This new species is superficially similar to
T. multipars (Walker, 1858 )
, but easily distinguished by the combination of the two spines of the paraphysis (
Figs. 67, 68
); pygofer caudoventral lobe broad and segment X ventral processes hooked apically (
Fig. 64
). It also resembles
T. fossa
Nielson, 1977
, but can be distinguished from the latter by the following: clypeus with longest band crossing lora and genae (
Fig. 63
) and two spines of paraphysis at apex and subapex, respectively (
Fig. 67
).
